dataset.title: Denitrification associated N loss in mangrove soil

address.deliveryPoint: Taiwan Forestry Research Institute, Taipei 100, Taiwan

abstract.para: The effect of salinity and nitrogen (NO3- and NH4+) on growth, nutrition and nitrogen uptake in Kandelia candel (L) Druce was investigated in phytroton condition. The experimental design was 4 × 2 factorial with four salinities (0, 0.88, 1.75 and 3.30 % NaCl) and two nitrogen sources (NO3- and NH4+). Nitrogen uptake rates were measured using 15N stable isotope technique. Biomass of shoot and root reduced with increasing salinity. Biomass ratio of root/shoot increased from 0.71 to 1.22 with increasing salinity (0 to 3.30 % NaCl salt) indicating reduction in the flux of water and nutrient transport. It was appeared that young seedlings of K. candel were salt tolerant and hypoctoyl acts as a buffer, regulate salt and nutrients. Increase in NaCl concentration from 0 to 3.30 % significantly reduced nitrogen content of leaf and root by 20 % and 57 % respectively. Nitrogen uptake was significantly reduced with increase in salinity. Nitrate and ammonium were utilized in more or less equal proportion at low salinity whereas NH4+ appears to be major source only at high salinity levels. N uptake patterns support the hypothesis that K. candel can utilize NO3- and NH4+ simultaneously as N source but salinity has strong bearing on it.

section.title: Denitrification as affected by soil depth
section.para: Soil samples were taken using PVC tubes (30 cm long and 1.5 cm inner diameter). The PVC tubes were stoppered on both ends and brought back to the laboratory in a cooler. The ration of actual lenght of soil samples in PVC tubes to the total lenght of PVC tubes inserted in the soil was used to determine the rate of compression. Soil samples were but into 3 cm pieces from the surface, taking into consideration the compression rate. As the mean compresson rate was about 0.6, each 3-cm section represented a 5-cm soil depth. Analysis of samples started within a few hours after sampling.
